timeline.bodyText:
There's actually a race condition here where the file is deleted between our checking it exists and trying to read it.  We should catch FileNotFoundException explicitly and just return silently because there's no stale file to delete.
Actually there's also a race condition where two processes might be checking the stale file, deleting and creating a new one at the same time as well...  ie both processes see a stale lock file, P1 deletes it and creates its own then P2 deletes that new file and creates its own. Both processes now think they hold the lock.
There's no perfect solution to this, but if we took out a FileChannel lock, read the file and deleted all while holding that lock at least two Teku instances wouldn't run into that problem.
timeline.author: ajsutton

replies.bodyText: Wouldn't one of the processes fail when trying to create a new one at the same time, with the same name?
replies.author: cemozerr

replies.bodyText: Turns out that file channel lock won't allow you to delete the file all while holding that lock: https://stackoverflow.com/q/53064571/13391299
replies.author: cemozerr

replies.bodyText: I also tested this and confirmed that is the case.
replies.author: cemozerr

replies.author: cemozerr

replies.bodyText:
Wouldn't one of the processes fail when trying to create a new one at the same time, with the same name?

No, the sequence would be that both check it's stale, one deletes and recreates, then the other deletes (the new file) and recreates.
Rather than deleting the file while it's stale, we could take a lock and just update the PID in the file. Just remember to get the lock, read and confirm it's stale and then write the new PID.
replies.author: ajsutton

timeline.bodyText: Rather than running an external program and sleeping, I'd suggest just using a really high value (probably Long.MAX_VALUE). Linux defaults to a max PID of 32768 and can only go up to 2^22 so it should be safe enough even if other OS's vary.
